document: Comprehensive lecture notes on the Medium Access Control (MAC) sublayer and the Network Layer. Includes details on Hubs, Bridges, Switches, VLANs, Packet Switching (Datagrams and Virtual Circuits), Routing Algorithms (Shortest Path, Flooding, Distance Vector, Link State, Hierarchical, Broadcast, Multicast), Congestion Control, Fragmentation, IPv4, IPv6, and ICMP.

questions.question: A Hub operates at the Data Link Layer (Layer 2) of the OSI model.
A Hub is essentially a multi-port repeater.
Hubs improve network performance by dividing collision domains.
When a Hub receives a bit on one port, it broadcasts it to all other ports.
All ports on a Hub share the same total bandwidth.
A Bridge operates at the Physical Layer (Layer 1).
Bridges forward frames based on MAC addresses.
A 'Learning Bridge' requires manual entry of all MAC addresses into its table.
Bridges can separate different LAN segments into distinct collision domains.
A Switch is effectively a multi-port bridge.
A Switch provides dedicated bandwidth to each of its ports.
Switches do not use MAC addresses to forward frames.
Cut-through switching allows a switch to start forwarding a frame before it is fully received.
VLAN stands for Virtual Local Area Network.
VLANs allow a network manager to group ports logically rather than physically.
A broadcast sent in VLAN 1 will be received by hosts in VLAN 2.
VLANs can help reduce the size of broadcast domains.
802.1Q is a common standard for VLAN tagging.
A VLAN-unaware switch can distinguish between different VLAN tags.
The primary responsibility of the Network Layer is node-to-node delivery.
The Network Layer is responsible for host-to-host delivery.
Store-and-forward packet switching means a router waits for the full packet to arrive before forwarding.
In a connectionless service, the network layer is often called a datagram network.
In a datagram network, all packets in a session must follow the same path.
Virtual-circuit subnets are connection-oriented.
A setup phase is required for datagram networks.
A setup phase is required for virtual-circuit networks.
In virtual circuits, each packet contains the full destination address.
In datagram networks, each packet contains the full destination address.
Routers in a virtual-circuit network must maintain state information for each connection.
Routing algorithms determine which output line an incoming packet should be transmitted on.
Adaptive routing algorithms do not change their decisions based on network traffic.
Static routing is a non-adaptive routing algorithm.
The Optimality Principle states that if router J is on the optimal path from I to K, then the path from J to K is also optimal.
A Sink Tree contains all possible paths between all nodes.
Dijkstra's algorithm is used to find the shortest path in a graph.
In Shortest Path routing, the 'cost' can be measured by delay, distance, or bandwidth.
Setting all link weights to 1 in Dijkstra's algorithm finds the path with the fewest hops.
Flooding involves sending a packet out on every line except the one it arrived on.
Basic flooding is highly efficient and uses very little bandwidth.
Selective flooding sends packets only in the direction of the destination.
Distance Vector routing is also known as the Bellman-Ford algorithm.
In Distance Vector routing, each router maintains a table giving the best-known distance to each destination.
Distance Vector routers share their entire routing tables with neighbors periodically.
Distance Vector routing converges very quickly when a link goes down.
The 'Count-to-Infinity' problem is a major drawback of Distance Vector routing.
Link State routing was designed to replace Distance Vector routing because it converges faster.
In Link State routing, routers only share information with their immediate neighbors.
Each Link State Packet (LSP) contains the identity of the sender and a sequence number.
Reliable flooding is used to distribute LSPs in Link State routing.
Hierarchical routing is used to manage routing tables in very large networks.
Hierarchical routing increases the size of routing tables.
In hierarchical routing, routers are divided into 'regions'.
Broadcast routing is the process of sending a packet to all nodes in a network.
Reverse Path Forwarding (RPF) is a technique used in broadcast routing.
In RPF, a router forwards a broadcast packet only if it arrived via the shortest path back to the source.
Multicast routing involves sending a packet to a specific subset of nodes.
IGMP is used by hosts to inform routers of their multicast group memberships.
An ad hoc network requires a fixed infrastructure like base stations.
Congestion occurs when the number of packets sent to the network is greater than its capacity.
Congestion control and flow control are exactly the same thing.
Congestion control is a global issue involving all hosts and routers.
Flow control is a point-to-point issue between a sender and a receiver.
Admission control is a congestion prevention technique used in virtual-circuit networks.
A 'Choke Packet' is used to tell a source to increase its transmission rate.
Load shedding is the process of dropping packets when a router is overwhelmed.
In load shedding for file transfer, it is better to drop old packets rather than new ones.
Traffic shaping is the process of smoothing out traffic bursts at the source.
Fragmentation is necessary when a packet is larger than the Maximum Transmission Unit (MTU) of a network link.
In transparent fragmentation, the fragments are reassembled at the final destination.
In non-transparent fragmentation, the fragments are reassembled at the final destination.
IPv4 addresses are 32 bits long.
IPv4 addresses are typically written in dotted-decimal notation.
The IP address 127.0.0.1 is used for loopback testing.
Class A IP addresses begin with a '0' bit.
Class C networks can support over 65,000 hosts.
Class D IP addresses are reserved for multicasting.
A subnet mask is used to divide a network into smaller subnets.
The default subnet mask for Class B is 255.255.0.0.
CIDR stands for Classless Inter-Domain Routing.
An IPv4 header contains a 'Time to Live' (TTL) field.
If the TTL field in an IP packet reaches 0, the packet is forwarded anyway.
The 'Protocol' field in the IPv4 header identifies the transport layer protocol (e.g., TCP or UDP).
The IPv4 header length (IHL) field is measured in 32-bit words.
The 'Identification' field is used to help reassemble fragmented packets.
IPv6 addresses are 64 bits long.
IPv6 addresses are 128 bits long.
IPv6 notation uses eight groups of four hexadecimal digits separated by colons.
The IPv6 header is simpler and has fewer fields than the IPv4 header.
IPv6 does not support fragmentation by intermediate routers.
In IPv6, only the source host can fragment a packet.
IPv6 has a checksum field in its main header.
Dual-stack is a transition mechanism where a device runs both IPv4 and IPv6.
Tunneling involves carrying IPv6 packets within IPv4 packets to cross IPv4-only networks.
ICMP stands for Internet Control Message Protocol.
ICMP messages are used to report errors in the processing of IP packets.
The 'ping' command uses ICMP Echo Request and Echo Reply messages.
Traceroute uses ICMP 'Time Exceeded' messages to discover the path to a destination.
ARP is used to map a MAC address to an IP address.
ARP is used to map an IP address to a MAC address.
DHCP is used to assign IP addresses to hosts dynamically.
NAT (Network Address Translation) allows multiple devices to share a single public IP address.
A Router operates at Layer 3 (Network Layer).
Bridges and Switches work with 'frames' while Routers work with 'packets'.
Link State routing uses the Dijkstra algorithm to calculate the shortest path.
Distance Vector routing is more likely to cause routing loops than Link State routing.
The Sink Tree is a DAG (Directed Acyclic Graph).
Flooding is useful in military applications where high robustness is required.
In Distance Vector, 'Good news travels fast, bad news travels slowly'.
Link State routing requires more memory and CPU than Distance Vector.
Hierarchical routing improves the optimality of the chosen path.
Multicast packets are addressed to a single destination host.
The Network Layer provides a service to the Transport Layer.
In connection-oriented services, a path is established before data transfer.
Fragmentation occurs when a router receives a packet that is too small for its output line.
The 'Fragment Offset' field in IPv4 tells where the fragment fits in the original packet.
IPv4 addresses are divided into five classes (A, B, C, D, E).
An IP address ending in 255 (for a Class C network) is usually a broadcast address.
A collision domain is a segment where two devices can send data at the same time and cause a collision.
A broadcast domain is the set of all devices that will receive a broadcast frame.
A Switch creates a separate collision domain for each port.
A Hub creates a single collision domain for all ports.
VLANs can span multiple physical switches.
The Network Layer is responsible for error-free delivery of bits over a physical link.
Packet switching is generally more efficient for bursty traffic than circuit switching.
In a virtual circuit, packets are delivered in the order they were sent.
In a datagram network, packets may be delivered out of order.
Routing is the process of moving packets from the source to the destination.
Static routing tables are updated automatically by routers.
Dynamic routing algorithms respond to changes in network topology.
Shortest path routing always considers only the physical distance.
Distance Vector routing can suffer from the 'Split Horizon' problem.
Split Horizon is a technique used to mitigate the count-to-infinity problem.
A Spanning Tree is a subset of a graph that includes all nodes with no cycles.
Reverse Path Forwarding is used to prevent broadcast loops.
Admission control can reject a new connection if the network is too busy.
Congestion can lead to packet loss and high delays.
A packet's 'Identification' field is changed by every router it passes through.
The 'Flags' field in an IPv4 header is used for fragmentation control.
The 'Don't Fragment' (DF) bit prevents a router from fragmenting a packet.
The 'More Fragments' (MF) bit indicates that more fragments are coming.
Private IP addresses (e.g., 192.168.x.x) are routable on the public internet.
An IPv6 address can be shortened by removing leading zeros in a group.
Double colons (::) can be used multiple times in an IPv6 address to represent zeros.
IPv6 provides better support for Quality of Service (QoS).
ICMP Destination Unreachable messages tell the source that a packet could not be delivered.
A Bridge maintains a table that maps MAC addresses to ports.
If a Bridge doesn't know the destination MAC address, it floods the frame.
Hubs are smarter than Switches.
VLAN tagging adds a header to the Ethernet frame.
The Network Layer is Layer 3 in the OSI model.
Packet switching uses 'statistical multiplexing'.
Circuit switching reserves a dedicated path for the duration of a call.
Virtual circuits are connection-oriented like circuit switching.
Routing decisions in datagram subnets are made on a packet-by-packet basis.
Link State routing requires each router to have a complete map of the network.
The Dijkstra algorithm is a greedy algorithm.
Flooding is used to distribute Link State advertisements.
The Bellman-Ford algorithm is used in RIP (Routing Information Protocol).
The 'infinity' value in RIP is 16.
Link State protocols generally scale better than Distance Vector protocols.
Multicasting is more bandwidth-efficient than sending multiple unicast packets.
A mobile host changes its point of attachment to the network over time.
Congestion control is easier in virtual-circuit subnets than in datagram subnets.
A 'Leaky Bucket' algorithm is used for traffic shaping.
Fragmentation can occur if a packet travels through a network with a smaller MTU.
The MTU of Ethernet is usually 1500 bytes.
Reassembling fragments at routers is more common than reassembling at the destination.
IPv4 addresses are becoming scarce.
A Class B network has 16 bits for the network ID.
10.0.0.0 to 10.255.255.255 is a private IP address range.
Subnetting allows a large network to be split into smaller, manageable pieces.
The IP header Checksum only covers the IP header, not the data.
The 'Version' field in an IP header is 4 bits long.
IPv6 addresses are written in decimal format.
The IPv6 'Hop Limit' field is equivalent to the IPv4 'TTL' field.
The IPv6 'Flow Label' field can be used for real-time traffic.
Transitioning from IPv4 to IPv6 can be done overnight for the whole internet.
ICMP messages are encapsulated within IP packets.
A 'Redirect' ICMP message tells a host to use a different router.
Bridges are faster than Hubs in processing bits.
A Switch can operate in full-duplex mode.
A Hub only operates in half-duplex mode.
VLANs provide a level of security by isolating traffic.
Network layer design should ideally be independent of the underlying technology.
Circuit switching is always better than packet switching.
Virtual circuits provide guaranteed quality of service more easily than datagrams.
A 'Router Table' is the same as a 'Forwarding Table'.
Distance Vector routing requires routers to know the entire network topology.
In Link State, every router runs Dijkstra's algorithm independently.
Broadcast storms can happen if there are loops in a bridge-based network.
Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) prevents loops in switched networks.
Hierarchical routing reduces the accuracy of the routing paths.
Mobile IP allows a device to keep its IP address while moving.
Congestion occurs when the input rate exceeds the output rate of a router for a prolonged period.
A 'Token Bucket' algorithm allows for some burstiness in traffic.
IP is a reliable, connection-oriented protocol.
IP is a 'best-effort' delivery protocol.
The total length of an IPv4 packet can be up to 65,535 bytes.
Fragment identifiers must be unique for each packet sent by a host.
Class C IP addresses have the first three bits set to '110'.
CIDR notation uses a slash (/) followed by the number of bits in the network prefix.
The IPv6 header does not have a Header Length field because it is fixed-length.
IPv6 addresses have a simplified structure for faster processing.
The 'Next Header' field in IPv6 is similar to the 'Protocol' field in IPv4.
IPv6 addresses are 4 times longer than IPv4 addresses.
The 'Parameter Problem' ICMP message indicates an error in a packet header field.
A Switch is a Layer 2 device.
A Bridge can connect two different types of LANs, like Ethernet and Token Ring.
Hubs increase the probability of collisions.
VLANs can be based on port numbers, MAC addresses, or IP addresses.
The Network Layer handles packet routing, but not packet addressing.
Datagram services are often referred to as 'unreliable'.
Virtual circuit IDs are local to each link.
Flooding ensures that a packet reaches its destination if a path exists.
Distance Vector routing is a decentralized algorithm.
The number of entries in a hierarchical routing table is smaller than in a flat routing table.
A 'Multicast Group' is identified by a specific IP address.
Congestion control is primarily a Transport Layer responsibility.
Packet loss due to congestion is a sign that the network is overloaded.
The 'Fragment Offset' is measured in units of 8 bytes.
The 'Total Length' field in an IP header includes both header and data.
IPv4 uses decimal numbers (0-255) while IPv6 uses hex (0-F).
A 'Subnet' is a logical subdivision of an IP network.
In Classless routing, there is no fixed boundary between network and host bits.
IPv6 was developed by the IETF to solve the address exhaustion problem.
The IPv6 address '::1' is the loopback address.
IP multicast uses Class D addresses.
The Network Layer is responsible for congestion control.
Every packet in a datagram subnet is routed independently.
Distance Vector routing uses the Bellman-Ford equation.
In Link State routing, routers broadcast their link-state information to all other routers.
Bridges increase the number of collision domains.
A Switch is essentially an intelligent Hub.
The primary goal of the Network Layer is to provide end-to-end communication.
ICMP messages are never sent in response to an ICMP error message.
